author: m.kalinin
content:
actually, in this example it will be:
1) 33.01 - 1 = 32.01
2) 32.01 + 1 = 33.01 < 32 + 1.25 => no EB update happens, EB = 32

But your previous example would play out a bit differently:
1) 41.178 ETH + 1.83 ETH = 43.008 > 41 + 1.25 => EB = 43, even though the balance is less than 43.25

author: jgm
content:
That makes it worse ðŸ™‚

Rather than someone running a 200 ETH validator, they will run two 100 ETH validators and as they reach 101 ETH they will withdraw from both and top up one, so you have a 100 ETH and a 102 ETH validator.  Next time round they will do the same but end up with two 102 ETH validators.

Active stake management appears to be a thing.  Not sure about the benefit, I'll try to run some numbers over the weekend.

author: jgm
content: (It may be that keeping back an amount of ETH to top up the 1 ETH deposit to be a 1.25 ETH deposit is more beneficial.  But the fact that there are potentially strategies that can be deployed here is concerning.)

author: m.kalinin
content: I agree, but i am not sure whether such strategies will be applied in practice. If we want to make it fair then i think we will have to split the logic of upwards into two parts: same as today if EB is lower than `MIN_ACTIVATION_BALANCE` and apply a strict hysteresis above that value. Alternatively, the new logic can be applied to compounding validators only
